#Text=Bring Your Desktop Computer to a Foreign Country
#Text=If you want to take your desktop computer with you to a foreign country , you may need to buy a current converter to make it work in some countries , including most of Portugal .
#Text=Steps
#Text=According to http://www.hoteltravel.com , the current in Portugal is " 220 volts AC , 50 Hz .

#Text=There should be a small window near the power switch with a red or orange tab showing that reads  115 " .

column1: #Text=Attached to this tab is a small orange switch that can be moved with a pen or small screwdriver .
#Text=This switch may be covered with a small label , to prevent accidental movement .
#Text=If you have this on the back of your CPU , it is made to handle dual currents .
#Text=You can confirm this by completely disconnecting the power supply , and then sliding the switch to one side ( toward the " 115 " ) .
#Text=This should reveal a similar small orange tab that says " 230 " .
#Text=You will still need a plug adapter to convert it to a type C or E plug .
#Text=If your computer does not have this capability built in , you will need to purchase a 230<->115 step down transformer to power your computer .
#Text=This , however , will not change the frequency of the current ( from 50Hz to 60 Hz ) , so you may experience a reduced life expectancy on your computer due to heat build up .
#Text=You will need the step down transformer to power most other peripherals , such as your monitor or printer , unless your CPU has outlets on the back that these connect to .
#Text=I suggest the somewhat higher priced ones with a built in power converter .
#Text=Tips

#Text=Check with your computer manufacturer via phone or online to find out more about your CPU 's capability of handling dual currents , and if using it with 50Hz current will reduce its life expectancy .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=DO NOT buy a cheap plug adapter to adapt the CPU 's plug to the European style unless it can handle dual current and unless you moved the switch on the back to the correct position !
